# Top Biglaw Firm That Started Special Bonus Craze Weighs In On New Salaries
## The firm is doing something a little special for first-years *and* ninth-years. Congrats!
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJune 18, 2021 at 12:01 PM
6
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/top-biglaw-firm-that-started-special-bonus-craze-weighs-in-on-new-salaries/&text=Top%20Biglaw%20Firm%20That%20Started%20Special%20Bonus%20Craze%20Weighs%20In%20On%20New%20Salaries)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/top-biglaw-firm-that-started-special-bonus-craze-weighs-in-on-new-salaries/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/top-biglaw-firm-that-started-special-bonus-craze-weighs-in-on-new-salaries/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
With millions of dollars’ worth of salaries soon to be increased across the legal landscape of large law firms, we couldn’t have but wonder: where would Biglaw associates be without Cooley?

If you recall, Cooley was the very first firm to [introduce special bonuses in Fall 2020](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/09/cooley-bonuses/), in appreciation for associates’ grueling work during the pandemic. Without Cooley’s first move, Davis Polk wouldn’t have been able to [swoop in and top those payments](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/09/wow-davis-polk-raises-the-bar-on-bonuses/), forcing other firms to match the new market standard. In a way, Cooley was the firm that finally got law firm leaders thinking about higher compensation for associates, and now here we are, less than one year later, looking at a $205K salary scale. On behalf of all associates, thank you, Cooley!

The firm — which came in at #19 in the most recent Am Law 100 ranking, having brought in $1,552,149,000 gross revenue in 2020 — is of course matching the new [Davis Polk salary scale](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/davis-polk-salary-21/), but it’s also doing something special for its youngest and its most experienced associates. Check out what the scale looks like at Cooley:

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
- 2021: $205,000
- 2020: $205,000
- 2019: $215,000
- 2018: $240,000
- 2017: $275,000
- 2016: $305,000
- 2015: $330,000
- 2014: $350,000
- 2013: $365,000
- 2012: $375,000
Cooley is not only offering a $205K salary to the Class of 2020, but the firm has joined in as one of the few that’s offering a salary bump up to $375K for ninth-year associates. This is just great. Congratulations to everyone at the firm!

(Flip to the next page to see the full memo from Cooley.)

We depend on your tips to stay on top of this stuff. So when your firm matches, please text us (646-820-8477) or [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Matches) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Matches”). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

### [ How Will Walgreens’ Expansion Into Specialty Pharmacy Affect The Industry? ](https://medcitynews.com/2024/04/walgreens-specialty-pharmacy-drugs/)
Walgreens announced that it is expanding its specialty pharmacy offerings. Experts think that this move could yield several strategic benefits, given the higher profit margins associated with specialty medications compared to traditional drugs. # Preparing For 2021 Legal Real Estate Trends
## Please join us on [November 18th](https://info.breakingmedia.com/preparing-for-2021-legal-real-estate-trends) to gain perspectives on how COVID-19 is impacting the legal real estate market and how to prepare for a future of uncertainty for your business.
By [Above The Law and Axiom](https://info.breakingmedia.com/preparing-for-2021-legal-real-estate-trends)  
onNovember 16, 2020 at 2:14 PMNovember 16, 2020 at 1:40 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/11/preparing-for-2021-legal-real-estate-trends/&text=Preparing%20For%202021%20Legal%20Real%20Estate%20Trends)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/11/preparing-for-2021-legal-real-estate-trends/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/11/preparing-for-2021-legal-real-estate-trends/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
As the COVID-19 pandemic continues to force a large portion of the workforce to work from home for the foreseeable future, and retail spaces are under pressure due to weakened demand, the real estate market continues to bear the brunt of this drastic acceleration in remote working and e-commerce, creating uncertainty and risk for 2021.

Attend this webinar on November 18th at 1 p.m. ET / 10 a.m. PT and learn from two real estate experts who will share their perspectives on how the pandemic is accelerating real estate trends and how to prepare to respond to these trends.

You will discover:

- How real estate trends will impact 2021
- Various approaches to consider when responding to current challenges
- Actions to take in Q4 to get ahead of these trends
Panelists:
Dustin Sarnoski, Global Head of Real Estate, State Street
John Skowronski, Real Estate Lawyer, Axiom
Sara Morgan, Vice President of Sales, Financial Services, Axiom

By submitting the form below, you are opting in to receive communication from Above the Law and its partners.

####Topics

# Biglaw Firm Wants Associates Off TikTok, Or At Least TikTok Off Their Phones
## Biglaw is trying to control more of associates' lives, but at least it's for a good reason.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onJuly 15, 2020 at 12:43 PMJuly 17, 2020 at 10:04 AM
12
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/07/biglaw-firm-wants-associates-off-tiktok-or-at-least-tiktok-off-their-phones/&text=Biglaw%20Firm%20Wants%20Associates%20Off%20TikTok,%20Or%20At%20Least%20TikTok%20Off%20Their%20Phones)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/07/biglaw-firm-wants-associates-off-tiktok-or-at-least-tiktok-off-their-phones/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/07/biglaw-firm-wants-associates-off-tiktok-or-at-least-tiktok-off-their-phones/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Associates at Ropes & Gray recently received a mandate from firm leadership telling them to delete TikTok. It doesn’t matter if it is firm issued or their personal electronics — any device that has access to their firm email has to be rid of the social media app.

In an email to associates, the firm said this mandate came after at least one client request. Last month, it was revealed that [TikTok, along with a host of other apps, was snooping](https://arstechnica.com/gadgets/2020/06/tiktok-and-53-other-ios-apps-still-snoop-your-sensitive-clipboard-data/) on anything on your device’s clipboard — which could include sensitive client information. TikTok, as well as some of the other apps, promised to do away with the practice. However, according to an Ars Technica report, at least TikTok was caught snooping even after they said they’d do away with the practice. So, now Ropes associates can’t have TikTok on their phones.

But though TikTok, with its Chinese ownership and Gen Z fan base, has gotten a lot of headlines over the practice, it is certainly not the only app that employs this security loophole. As of June 30, the following apps still [reportedly](https://arstechnica.com/gadgets/2020/06/tiktok-and-53-other-ios-apps-still-snoop-your-sensitive-clipboard-data/) read the data you have on the clipboard: Fox News, New York Times, Reuters, Vice News, Huffington Post, The Wall Street Journal, Fruit Ninja, Plants v. Ninja Heroes, Bed Bath & Beyond, Overstock, Accuweather, Zoosk, and more.
